II. 

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

 
A. 
 
2. 
With  poverty  incidence  estimated  at  38%,  Nepal  is  one  of  the  poorest  countries  in  the 
world.  Poverty  is  concentrated  in  rural  areas  where  its  incidence  (44%)  is  almost  double  that  in 
urban areas (23%). The incidence of poverty in the Midwestern and Far Western regions (72%) 
and  in  the  mountain  districts  (56%)  is  much  greater  than  the  national  average.  The  hill  and 
mountain  districts  of  the  Midwestern  and  Far  Western  regions  rank  the  lowest  in  terms  of 
socioeconomic and infrastructure development. They have substantially lower livelihood indicators 
and  road  densities  than  other  areas  of  Nepal,  and  limited  market  access  worsens  their  poverty. 
Disadvantaged  ethnic  groups  and  castes  in  these  districts  are  among  the  poorest  people  in  the 
country, with human development indicators significantly lower than those for other caste groups. 
Such  deprivation,  inequality,  and  discrimination  have  contributed  to  the  spread  of  the  conflict  in 
Nepal.  
 
The development of the strategic road network (SRN)2 has long been a government priority, 
3. 
resulting  in  around  3,000  kilometers  (km)  of  national  highways  providing  the  main  strategic 
connections nationwide, and nearly 2,000 km of feeder roads connecting highways to regional and 
district headquarters and to major economic centers. Within about 2 years all but five of the hill and 
mountain  district  centers  should  be  connected  to  the  SRN.  Nepal  has  an  estimated  6,600  km  of 
district roads, most of which are earthen. The Department of Local Infrastructure Development and 
Agricultural  Roads  (DOLIDAR)  has  estimated  that  the  country  has  14,000  km  of  rural  roads  (in 
districts and villages), but over 25% are officially listed as not motorable. About 130,000 km of main 
trails and at least 900 pedestrian suspension bridges are estimated to exist. Most people in remote 
hill and mountain districts live more than a day’s walk from a road, and overall poverty increases with 
poorer physical access. A number of districts have no roads at all, and in most districts road density 
is  0.5–1.7  km  per  100  square  km,  and  0.9–2.7  km  per  10,000  people.  Only  districts  with  feeder 
roads  have  substantially  higher  figures.  These  data  compare  poorly  with  Ninth  Five-Year  Plan 
targets of 8 km and 4 km, respectively.3  
 
While considerable efforts have been made in the past decade to strengthen maintenance

has created an independent Road Board with a road maintenance fund. About 30% of the fund’s

B. 
 
The  conflict  has  displaced  about  400,000  landowners,  and  directly  affected  about  2.4 
5. 
million people, primarily in the three western regions. Infrastructure (primarily government offices, 
and police stations, rather than roads and other infrastructure) has been damaged and economic 
activity disrupted, with direct impacts on the livelihoods of millions of rural dwellers. Disruption of 
agricultural  activities  and  markets,  and  migration  and  displacement  of  productive  workers  have 
undermined  food  security,  particularly  in  western  Nepal.  Two  key  problems  constraining  poverty 
reduction in rural hill and mountain areas are the adverse terrain and low agricultural productivity. 
These  are  linked  because  poor  access  to  inputs,  services,  and  markets  due  to  rugged  terrain 
makes it hard to increase agricultural productivity. Improved physical access is a prerequisite for 
significant economic development, mainly through reduced transport costs, leading to (i) increased 
consumer  spending,  (ii)  diversified  agricultural  production,  (iii)  better  provision  of  services  by 
government  agencies,  (iv)  greater  use  of  services  and  facilities,  and  (v)  better  access  to 
information and knowledge of development opportunities. A subsector analysis is in Appendix 1. 
 
6. 
Since  the  1960s  the  Government’s  strategy  has  been  to  develop  the  SRN  linking 
Kathmandu  to  the  borders,  main  administrative  centers,  and  major  economic  centers.  The  next 
stage is to reduce poverty through a substantial increase of the SRN. Construction of rural roads 
connecting to strategic roads is guided by targets in the national 5-year plans, but otherwise is left 
to individual DDCs to plan through district transport master plans (DTMPs). The last 10 years have 
seen a major shift of external funding agency support to rural roads, with increasing emphasis on 
poverty  reduction  as  a  goal  rather  than  economic  growth  stimulated  by  increased  agricultural 
production. The pressing need throughout Nepal for basic infrastructure, which is expensive given 
the  difficult  terrain,  has  led  to  reliance  on  external  assistance  to  provide  the  initial  capital 
investment (Appendix 2). Asian Development Bank (ADB), World Food Programme, World Bank, 
United Kingdom’s Department for International Development, Swiss Agency for Development and 
Cooperation  (SDC),  Government  of  Germany’s  Gesellschaft  für  Technische  Zusammenarbeit 
(GTZ), Netherlands Development Organization, and other external funding agencies are active in 
the sector. Shared experience has led to a convergence of project approaches, and joint initiatives 
are  now  common  and  will  be  used  by  the  Project.  The  project  approaches  all  aim  to  reduce 
poverty  and  improve  livelihoods,  using  local  infrastructure  development  as  a  means  to  an  end 
rather than, as previously, an end in itself. 
 
While reliable transport infrastructure is a prerequisite for poverty reduction and economic 
7. 
growth, the broader issue of social access is of fundamental importance. Roads have stimulated 
economic growth and high levels of social well-being in the areas served, but can also contribute 
to polarization between different areas and communities—a factor in the conflict in Nepal. The lack 
of education, depth of poverty, high degree of social exclusion of many groups, and vulnerability of 
most  subsistence  livelihoods  all  point  to  the  need  for  interventions  much  broader  than  the 
construction of roads, bridges, and trails alone. Previous road projects have not always enabled 
many  disadvantaged  groups  to  benefit  from  the  opportunities  and  services  that  the  roads  were 
assumed to generate or deliver.

Sectoral  programs  have  sought  to  expand  the  delivery  of  services  to  rural  areas  rather 
8. 
than  concentrate  solely  on  building  infrastructure.  The  strategy  of  providing  roads  has  benefited 
rural people but not adequately raised living standards. Building on lessons learned (Appendix 1), 
a different strategy is clearly required if significant poverty reduction is to be achieved in remote 
areas  affected  by  the  conflict.  Lessons  learned  show  that  substantial  infrastructure  investments, 
combined with community development and livelihood enhancement, are required to improve rural 
incomes and welfare. A specific effort must be made to provide the poorest groups with income-
earning opportunities. This can be achieved by hiring the poor as unskilled labor to construct roads 
through hilly terrain. Methods of mobilizing and managing building groups (BGs) formed by poor 
households have been developed and tested by a number of projects, including, on a pilot basis, 
ADB’s Rural Infrastructure Development Project.4 This approach provides immediate cash income 
but, perhaps more important, boosts social capital of the most disadvantaged in rural society. The 
approach  also  provides  a  point  of  entry  for  broad  social  development  interventions  to  promote 
other  livelihood  improvements  in  conflict  areas.  When  coupled  with  enhanced  physical  access, 
this integrated approach leads to a significant positive impact on the rural poor’s living standard.  
 
Implementing  development  projects  in  conflict  areas  is  difficult  and  subject  to  rapidly 
9. 
changing conditions that are location specific. However, short- and medium-term interventions to 
address the immediate consequences of the conflict, such as disruption of livelihoods and damage 
to  infrastructure,  are  urgently  needed.  Recent  experience  in  ADB's  Rural  Infrastructure

incorporate  conflict  sensitivity,  involve  the  cooperation  of  nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs)

overcome  economic  and  social  inequalities  and  discrimination  (para.  55).  The  Tenth  Five-Year

and support the integrated approach to rural development described in para. 8.

24. 
The  project  components  are  primarily  focused  on  poverty  reduction  and  livelihood 
restoration  in  conflict-affected  districts  rather  than  infrastructure  development  alone.  The 
components are integrated, with the infrastructure built using appropriate, labor-based methods as 
the entry point for rural livelihood-enhancement interventions. Numerous small BGs, formed locally 
from the poorest people of the community, will undertake construction work. These BGs form the 
initial basis of project efforts to boost human and social capital. Disadvantaged castes and ethnic 
minorities are predominantly found in the poorest  groups and will be specifically targeted by the 
Project for BG membership and life-skill training. Poor women from these groups will be directly 
targeted  to  join  BGs  and  will  receive  full  training  and  a  support  program  aimed  at  the  multiple 
dimensions of poverty. This program will help reduce poverty by addressing the many influences 
on  livelihoods  and  poverty,  and  offer  immediate  income-earning  opportunities.  The  community 
development  component  will  enable  these  groups  to  participate  fully  in  community  decision 
making. All of these activities will seek to mitigate the adverse impacts of the conflict and its root 
causes.

The  Project’s  emphasis  on  participation  includes  active  community  involvement  in 
planning  supplementary  investments  to  enhance  rural  livelihoods  and  restore  incomes  in

investment is, therefore, process based rather than prescriptive, and as a result project planning 
has  only  provided  indicative  guidelines  for  the  kinds  and  scales  of  investment  that  will  be 
determined during implementation. In a wider process that underpins support for construction of 
physical infrastructure, social mobilizers will ensure that all local people gain access and livelihood 
benefits from the project activities.

Rural  Roads.  A  system  of  rural  roads  and  trails  provides  access  to  rural  areas  from 
administrative centers and the SRN. In the last two decades efforts have increased to build rural 
roads to the hills, including initiatives by local authorities (district development committees [DDCs]

suggest  that  the  country  has  about  6,600  kms  of  district  roads,  two  thirds  of which are earthen, 
and a maximum of perhaps 4,000 km of earthen trafficable village roads.

4. 
The  Labor-Based,  Environmentally  Friendly,  and  Participatory  Approach  to  Rural 
Road  Construction.  The  “green  roads”  approach  was  originally  developed  in  Nepal  under  a 
program financed by the Government of Germany’s Gesellschaft für Technische Zusammenarbeit 
(GTZ).  DOLIDAR  has  adopted  the  approach,  formalizing  it  as  labor-based,  environmentally 
friendly,  and  participatory  (LEP).  It  is  intended  to  (i)  employ  local  people,  rather  than  use  heavy 
equipment, to build roads; (ii) apply design and construction methods that minimize the damage 
to, and where possible, enhance the fragile physical environment in hill areas; and (iii) incorporate 
local  interests  and  opinions  in  the  planning,  design,  implementation,  and  management  of  rural 
road infrastructure. The LEP approach is in stark contrast to uncontrolled rural road construction 
that  continues  to  be  practiced  by  local  authorities.  Often  unplanned,  badly  excavated, 
unmaintainable  (and  frequently  impassable)  earth  tracks  are  constructed  with  bulldozers, 
significantly damaging the environment.

PROJECT CONCEPT AND APPROACH 
 

Overview of Project Concept 

A. 
 
The concepts used in the project design are based on the premise, widely proven in Nepal, 
1. 
that physical infrastructure alone is not enough to significantly reduce poverty. While access is a 
prerequisite for sustainable improvements in the livelihoods of the poor, specific measures must 
be  taken  to  ensure  that  interventions  immediately  ameliorate  the  living  conditions  of  the  most 
marginalized  sections  of  society,  restore  incomes  and  community  infrastructure  affected  by  the 
conflict, and are then translated into long-term, lasting changes to assets, be they financial, social, 
or other capital. This approach can be simply demonstrated by means of the three main project 
components. The project design ensures that the three components are integrally linked to enable 
the  infrastructure  investments  to  be  used  as  a  sustainable,  long-term  approach  to  poverty 
reduction.  
 
2. 
Community  Development  and  Rural  Livelihood  Restoration.  The  inequalities  in  rural 
communities have led to the widespread failure of disadvantaged groups to benefit from previous 
top-down interventions that have been captured by a small but relatively wealthy elite, except for 
some  trickle-down  benefits,  one  of  the  causes  of  the  conflict  in  Nepal.  The  Project  will  reduce 
poverty by raising awareness of rights and opportunities among all parts of the communities, and 
ensuring  that  project  interventions  provide  direct  practical  support  for  the  poorest  groups.  The 
Project will use a coordinated, intensive, and wide-reaching series of social mobilization actions so 
people can build assets, revise livelihood strategies, and have a secure and sustainable existence. 
 
Capacity Building and Decentralized Local Governance. As decentralization continues 
3. 
(paras. 8-10), the Project will seek to build the capacity, and clearly define the appropriate level of 
authority, of local government institutions to enable them to perform their functions efficiently, and 
to  operate  as  effective,  accountable  service  providers.  Central  institutions  are  not  adapted  to  a 
modern  governance  role  as  facilitators  and  regulators  of  development  activities.  The  Project  will 
seek to reform and build new capacity in the Department of Local Infrastructure Development and 
Agricultural Roads (DOLIDAR) to facilitate and regulate the rural road sector. 
 
Rural Transport Infrastructure. This component will depart from the traditional approach 
4. 
used in previous rural infrastructure interventions. Supported by the community development and 
capacity-building components, the component will be used to promote community development by 
financing  subprojects  to  construct  new,  or  rehabilitate  existing,  rural  transport  infrastructure 
planned using a participatory approach, and built by employing local poor people in labor-based 
construction that uses environmentally sound techniques. Long-term livelihood enhancement and 
income    restoration  depends  on  all  of  these  elements  being  followed,  and  subsequent 
sustainability requires establishment of a maintenance management system based on the same 
approach. 
 
5. 
Process  Approach.  The  rural  transport  infrastructure  component  cannot  be  achieved 
through a prescriptive list of interventions. A process approach will be used that allows the districts 
to select subprojects through participatory planning mechanisms, and, within the subproject areas, 
allows the beneficiary communities to select and design supplementary investments in social and 
economic infrastructure that, combined with the social mobilization activities, will enable people to 
better access services and markets.

incidents where work was hampered were only temporary.  
 
17. 
Given the project objectives, the situation is likely to remain as it is now and the Project to 
operate relatively unhindered. However, the security situation changes frequently and is location 
specific. Regular monitoring will therefore be required (para. 20). Some projects have been most 
easily  able  to  continue  where  they  are  already  well  known.  To  continue,  the  projects  need  to 
maintain  an  informal  dialogue  with  the  insurgents;  focus  on  activities  with  a  direct,  visible,  and 
rapid  developmental  and  employment  impact  (construction  of  infrastructure  and  income 
restoration,  for  example,  rather  than  conduct  of  workshops);  and  heed  periodic  advice  to  avoid 
certain areas. Transparency in implementation is also an important risk-mitigation strategy. 
 
18. 
The Project can achieve quick recognition in two ways. One is to enter into partnerships 
with  ongoing  projects,  which  will  facilitate  implementation  since  these  are  well  known  and 
established  at  the  local  level,  and  recognized  as  doing  valuable  work.  In  practice  this  means 
linkages  with  the  District  Road  Support  Program  in  the  Central  and  Eastern  districts  of 
Okhaldhunga and Ramechhap, and with the Rural Community Infrastructure Works Programme in 
the Far Western districts of Baitadi, Bajhang, Bajura, and Darchula. For the other districts, where 
partnership  agreements  may  not  be  possible,  the  second  way  is  to  begin  activities  carefully, 
starting  modestly  and  expanding  the  Project’s  presence  gradually,  in  close  consultation  and 
dialogue with all concerned parties. This will allow the development of operational procedures that 
are practical, acceptable, and safe in a conflict situation, and that will develop the confidence of all 
local stakeholders, including those directly involved in the conflict. 
 
19.  Working in a conflict environment inevitably implies an element of risk to the safety of the 
individuals  involved,  combined  with  risks  of  loss  of  project  property  and  funds,  and  even  of  the

districts;  (ii)  the  need  to  train  all  project  field  staff  to  be  effective  in  a  conflict  situation,  and  to

evacuate  field  staff  promptly  if  the  security  risk  becomes  unacceptable.  In  the  context  of  an

1. 
The beneficiaries in the Ratnechaur-Bhakimli village road subproject illustrate the Project’s 
poverty  focus.  Disadvantaged  groups  compose  24%  of  households.  Females  head  26%  of 
households,  and  63%  of  households  have  sent  income-earning  members  to  work  away  from 
home.  Most  households  (76%)  depend  on  agriculture  for  their  livelihoods.  On  average, 
households  can  grow  food  sufficient  to  last  only  7.8  months  a  year.  All  agricultural  daily-wage 
workers  were  from  the  disadvantaged  castes  and  have  little  or  no  land  to  grow  food.  The 
disadvantaged castes have the smallest average plot sizes and the lowest food security at around 
5.0-6.5 months of the year. Only three households (1% of project-affected families) can produce 
sufficient  food  to  feed  their  households  year  round,  and  no  other  household  can  feed  itself  for 
more than 8.5 months. The average income per capita of the sample households is NRs12,957, 
compared  to  the  national  average  income  per  capita  poverty  level  of  NRs13,065  (national  living 
standard survey figures for poverty in Nepal in 1996, factored to 2004 levels). Household income 
in  the  survey  households  is  boosted  by  pensions  and  remittances,  without  which  these 
households would be even poorer.  
 
2. 
The Project will improve physical access to economic opportunities and social services. 
The  extension  into  rural  areas  of  a  more  efficient  and  sustainable  transport  network  is  an 
essential  starting  point  and  a  prerequisite  for socioeconomic development. About 52% of total 
project costs will be allocated to construction of new, and rehabilitation of existing, rural roads to 
motorable  standard;  improvement  of  main  trails;  and  construction  of  trail  bridges.  The 
supplementary  investments  in  small,  community  physical  infrastructure  schemes  (about  9%  of 
total costs) within the vicinity of the transport infrastructure subprojects will increase the impact 
of the road and trail investments.

and  disadvantaged  in  planning  and  implementation  so  that  they  benefit  directly  from  the
